promptUsed.user:

@arixoneth yeah their only options would be to extract more or exit

also bandwidth costs have to be pretty non-trivial even if they are using data centres for cheap hardware

Seeing a lot of misunderstandings about this SIMD.

The reason it was rejected was because validators made the right economic choice.

Absent SOL emissions, these validators would need to begin extracting a lot more  in order to be profitable, or simply operate at a loss.

What we saw as a result of SIMD is that no matter how much IBRL is spammed on the timeline, the economics of running a validator can‚Äôt be ignored.

The cost to validate on sol is very very high. The cost to even run a full node is very very high.

That means you can‚Äôt just do minimal viable issuance like ethereum wants to, because on eth, validators have very modest hardware and bandwidth requirements, they do not operate at a loss the same way other chains do.

Ethereum also doesn‚Äôt have massive foundation based subsidies for validators either, these validators validate because it is profitable to do so!

Ppl often forget how mature and sound Ethereum‚Äôs are economics are, but you can be quickly reminded by just looking under the hood of other chains.

>‚Äúbut to do this we just need to extract less from the actual users/retail of the chain -- let's do what is best and grow the pie together, yay or nay?‚Äù

You read this wrong, it‚Äôs literally the opposite.

This SIMD would mean that the only way validators could sustain is by extracting MEV. They would literally need to extract more to make up for it.

@_MouseDev @networkspirits <3

This may not seem like much, but it means a lot to our team.

To the first of many thousands more to come ü´°

For real though all L1 designs eventually converge on the rollup-centric roadmap, just in different form factors.

Through that lens it's almost intuitive that the chain which acknowledges and build towards that reality is the one that's best positioned long term.

Rollups with small quorum or single sequencer designs were right.

@networkspirits @Truemarketsorg hi

Same vibes https://t.co/9TMu7lSfkd

The reason ppl have this extractive view of the chain is because the ecosystem has hardly produced anything new, has created little open source value, and has played deceptive narrative games for years.

The fact that ‚ÄúMEV‚Äù infra is the most funded thing on that chain right now is literal evidence of that.

In 2023, Ethereum was criticized by podcasters because there was too much focus on MEV and scaling infra by VCs.

In 2021, the solana narrative was that It didn‚Äôt have evil extractive MEV like ethereum does, that blocks were produced so fast that the demand for ordering preference just magically evaporates. 

This was literally touted by sol leadership and others in crypto media.

Today, the entire value prop and narrative for solana is that you stake SOL to earn MEV. 

They went from saying MEV is evil and doesn‚Äôt exist on solana to building the entire ecosystem on top of it. They even try to rally behind a new (rather unoriginal) name for MEV as if it erases this history.

In 2020 Ethereum created a ton of net new use cases and open source protocols that are the basis and foundation of all onchain applications that exist today, on all chains, regardless of the VM being used.

There was a wealth effect that had legitimacy to it. Something legitimately new was being experimented with in real time.

But for the past year, nearly all the activity on Solana has been purely extractive, with little produced value for the industry. 

For those who don‚Äôt know, MEV literally stands for Maximal Extractable Value. And this is now the basis of the sol ecosystem. Something which wasn‚Äôt supposed to exist.

MEV.  It‚Äôs literally in the name.

@fozzydiablo https://t.co/BdHFdHTTn9

@0xdoug That‚Äôs basically what Arbitrum does right?

@_ryanrconnor God you lose more credibility by the day

summary: The main topics in the tweets from @MilliŒû over the past week include issues with censorship on a platform, discussions about web2 services, observations and opinions on various blockchain projects like Solana and Ethereum, commentary on market trends and predictions, insights into the economics of running validators on different chains, and updates on the launch of Truemarkets. The sentiments expressed range from frustration with censorship and technical challenges to critical analysis of blockchain ecosystems and their development. There is also a sense of excitement and engagement with the community around market activities and new project launches.
